matters by getting the terms from
Messrs. Sears or Richardson, and
having their pictures taken as soon
as possible. The various class pictures also should be taken at once.
The 1913 class history and the individual anecdotes are already under way, as is the class prophecy,
under the direction of Messrs.
Uhler and Dickinson, that there
may be no delay when the time
comes to put the book in the printer's hands. Mr. Richardson repeated that over half the probable
cost of bringing -the book out is in
his hands and that he looks for
no trouble in obtaining the rest.
He repeated further that a regular
ad. getter will be engaged at a 25
per cent. rate and that he is willing to give the members of the
University the same rates. Those
who wish to try for ads. should apply to him for a list of those firms
which have not been -signed up.
Finally, he requested that all those
who want a copy of the Hullabaloo
should let him know at their earliest convenience so that he may ascertain how many copies will be
needed and not have to disappoint
anyone.

"know-how" in
Co-operative Buying.

Attention is called to the letter
received from Graduate Manager
Harry C. Burgan and published in
this issue of THE NEWS-LETTER.
Mr. Burgan has opened up the way
to supply a long-felt want of the
student body; namely, some adequate method of securing athletic
supplies at the low rates which can
only be obtained when large purchases are made. During the University year quite a sum of money
is spent by the students for athletic
supplies. Heretofore, this money
has been spent at random in making small, individual purchases. No
method was open to the students
by which they could work together
in the matter of purchasing supplies
for the mutual benefit of all concerned.
Since his election as graduate
manager, Mr. Burgan has accomplished much in the way of systematizing the purchases of the athletic supplies for the various teams
and has saved quite a considerable
amount of money to the Athletic
Association. His new proposal of
co-operative buying not only benefits the students, but will also benefit the Athletic Association by enabling Mr. Burgan to secure still
lower rates as a result of the increased amount of goods that will
be thus purchased. The students
should avail themselves of the opportunity now afforded them and
give the co-operative buying plan
their hearty support.

Co-operative Buying.

January 9, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

As the various teams of the Athletic Association are continually
purchasing supplies of various
kinds—in fact, of practically every
variety of athletic goods—we are
in a position to enable individual
students to save money by allowing
them to buy their athletic supplies
through the Association.
At present, this applies particularly to sweaters in the University
colors, in practically all of the usual
styles. These can be obtained at
special, rates until January 17, 1913.
The advantage to the Association
consists in our being able to purchase in larger quantities, thereby
making our trade more desirable to
dealers and consequently securing
better rates.
I shall be glad to talk to any students who may wish to take advantage of this offer.
Very truly yours,
H. C. BURGAN,
Graduate Manager.

Musical Clubs.

The successful concert at Rockville by the Musical Clubs of the
University has put everyone connected with them in hopes of even
better things yet to come. Practices
are being regularly held, and all
the little wrinkles and creases in the
music are being carefully pressed
out by the several leaders. They
promise that at the next concert
every "crescendo" and every "rallantando" wil receive its due value.
The managers of the clubs on their
side are endeavoring to work up as
attractive a schedule as possible.
On January 21 the clubs will give a
concert at St. Michael's and All
Angels Church. It is expected and
hoped that this concert will materially aid the finances of the club, so
that no one will have evil forebodings on January 25 when the clubs
will make a trip to Salisbury
Soon after this concert the musicians are planning to make an excursion to Western Maryland and
show the people of Cumberland
what good music and dancing really
is. The date for this concert has
not, as yet, been definitely settled,
but it will probably be about February 1. Another thing for the
clubs to look forward to is the proposed joint concert with Goucher

Missionary Convention to be Held.

The annual Maryland convention
of the Student Volunteer Movement for Foreign Missions will be
held at the Woman's College of
Frederick on January 31 and February I and 2.
The convention will be attended
by both men and women delegates
from the colleges of the State.
Last year the convention was held
at Western Maryland College and
was attended by about two hundred
delegates. Twenty-five men went
from Hopkins and about the same
number of girls from Goucher.
The object of the convention is
not only to bring before the students the need of workers and the
great opportunity for service
abroad, but also to discuss the
means of arousing a greater interest
in missions among the students of
our Maryland colleges. It brings
the workers from the various col- .
leges into closer touch and thus

Baltimore, Md.
broadens the outlook of each one.
Reports are made and plans for the
ensuing year discussed.
It is hoped that this year Hopkins may be able to have as many
delegates as before. All who desire to know more about the conference can see either Alec Barton,
'14, Bud Wagner, '12, or any of
the men who went to Westminister
last year. They will tell you that
it not only gives one the great time
that necessarily conies when a large
body of students get together, but
that it is a time when one's horizon in broadened and one is made
to see beyond his own college walls.
As the number of delegates will be
limited it is best to see about this
at once.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 13, 1913.

FOOTBALL BLOWOUT IN GYM
About One Hundred Present, and Affair
Voted Huge Success— Mr. B. Howell
Griswold the Principal Speaker.

The usual football blowout and
Jollification meeting was held in the
gymnasium last Thursday evening.
Almost one hundred members of the
University were present. "Freddie"
Lee was chairman of the meeting
and called for speeches from the
various captains. Captain Huck of
the lacrosse team evidently believed
that "brevity is the soul of wit,"
..and so showed his wit by being
brief. Captain Pieper prophesied
a •successful baseball season and
urged undergraduates in particular
to come out for the team. As an
inducement he read the attractive
schedule Manager Getz has prepared. Captain Leibensperger of
the football team next delivered an
oration upon the "queer" season
that we have just completed and
offered hopes of brighter things
to come. Catlin spoke for the
track team, promising events with
Carlisle, Virginia, Pennsylvania,
Georgetown and Franklin and Marshall. Mr. B. Howell Griswold,
Jr., was the principal speaker. He
urged the athletes to practice "optimism" and not get discouraged because of defeat and try to make a
weaker schedule. "Nothing," he
he said, "is too good for Johns
Hopkins."
Then came the awarding of honors. Dr. Abercrombie awarded
medals to the members of the winning gymnasium team of the 1915
_Class. Hutzler receiv'ed a cup for
first place and Swartz a medal for
second. Dr. Magoffin next awarded the "H," the "H. A. A." and
the "H. M" to the deserving members of the football team. At the
same time they were given their
sweaters. Those, too, who had not
received their sweaters or letters
for last spring's lacrosse, baseball
and track work were rewarded
then.
Several short speeches were made
by "Pete" Porter, Tappan, Hulburt
and Burgan. At intervals the assembled crowd was convulsed with
laughter by the antics of the "Ragamuffin Trio." Their program consisted of choice selections from the
operas, impromptus and fancy buck
dancing. They put everyone into
good spirits and made them ready
to enjoy to the full the bounteous
supply of "eats" the committe'e had
provided. No one went'away
hungry.
Cotillon on January 31.

The Board of Governors of the
Cotillon Club met last Tuesday and
announced that the next cotillon
would take place on Friday, January 31. At the meeting various
duties were assigned to each of the
governors, and attempts are being
made to make the next dance an extremely successful and pleasing affair. The names of those who will
receive have not yet been announced.

Hopkins Publicity.

• In spite of the criticism of the
Class of 1902 in regard to the publicity given to the new department
of technology, it appears from the
statement of Dr. Buchner that considerable has been done to make
known the existence of the technical school by methods which, in the
judgment of those in charge of the
matter, would be the most efficacious.
As Dr. Buchner stated to a representative of THE NEWS-LETTER,
graduates of Johns Hopkins who
are at present teaching at other institutions can do the most to boom
.their alma mater. They have done
so in the past and will, undoubtedly, continue to do so. It must be
remembered, however, that they
usually advocate their alma mater
because of her reputation in the
fields in which they are particularly
interested. Now it is obvious that
Hopkins has no professors at other
colleges who are graduates from
her technical school, as the technical course is offered for the first
.time this year. The Hopkins alumni teaching at other institutions are
probably greatly pleased over the
establishment of the department of
technology. Many of them have
probably mentioned the department to their students, but it is
quite certain that they are not working as hard for the technical school
as the Hopkins technical school
graduates will be working for it
twenty or thirty years hence.

available means should be used to
keep this new department before

"know-how" in
Co-operative Buying.

Attention is called to the letter
received from Graduate Manager
Harry C. Burgan and published in
this issue of THE NEWS-LETTER.
Mr. Burgan has opened up the way
to supply a long-felt want of the
student body; namely, some adequate method of securing athletic
supplies at the low rates which can
only be obtained when large purchases are made. During the University year quite a sum of money
is spent by the students for athletic
supplies. Heretofore, this money
has been spent at random in making small, individual purchases. No
method was open to the students
by which they could work together
in the matter of purchasing supplies
for the mutual benefit of all concerned.
Since his election as graduate
manager, Mr. Burgan has accomplished much in the way of systematizing the purchases of the athletic supplies for the various teams
and has saved quite a considerable
amount of money to the Athletic
Association. His new proposal of
co-operative buying not only benefits the students, but will also benefit the Athletic Association by enabling Mr. Burgan to secure still
lower rates as a result of the increased amount of goods that will
be thus purchased. The students
should avail themselves of the opportunity now afforded them and
give the co-operative buying plan
their hearty support.

Co-operative Buying.

January 9, 1913.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

As the various teams of the Athletic Association are continually
purchasing supplies of various
kinds—in fact, of practically every
variety of athletic goods—we are
in a position to enable individual
students to save money by allowing
them to buy their athletic supplies
through the Association.
At present, this applies particularly to sweaters in the University
colors, in practically all of the usual
styles. These can be obtained at
special, rates until January 17, 1913.
The advantage to the Association
consists in our being able to purchase in larger quantities, thereby
making our trade more desirable to
dealers and consequently securing
better rates.
I shall be glad to talk to any students who may wish to take advantage of this offer.
Very truly yours,
H. C. BURGAN,
Graduate Manager.

Musical Clubs.

The successful concert at Rockville by the Musical Clubs of the
University has put everyone connected with them in hopes of even
better things yet to come. Practices
are being regularly held, and all
the little wrinkles and creases in the
music are being carefully pressed
out by the several leaders. They
promise that at the next concert
every "crescendo" and every "rallantando" wil receive its due value.
The managers of the clubs on their
side are endeavoring to work up as
attractive a schedule as possible.
On January 21 the clubs will give a
concert at St. Michael's and All
Angels Church. It is expected and
hoped that this concert will materially aid the finances of the club, so
that no one will have evil forebodings on January 25 when the clubs
will make a trip to Salisbury
Soon after this concert the musicians are planning to make an excursion to Western Maryland and
show the people of Cumberland
what good music and dancing really
is. The date for this concert has
not, as yet, been definitely settled,
but it will probably be about February 1. Another thing for the
clubs to look forward to is the proposed joint concert with Goucher

Missionary Convention to be Held.

The annual Maryland convention
of the Student Volunteer Movement for Foreign Missions will be
held at the Woman's College of
Frederick on January 31 and February I and 2.
The convention will be attended
by both men and women delegates
from the colleges of the State.
Last year the convention was held
at Western Maryland College and
was attended by about two hundred
delegates. Twenty-five men went
from Hopkins and about the same
number of girls from Goucher.
The object of the convention is
not only to bring before the students the need of workers and the
great opportunity for service
abroad, but also to discuss the
means of arousing a greater interest
in missions among the students of
our Maryland colleges. It brings
the workers from the various col- .
leges into closer touch and thus

Baltimore, Md.
broadens the outlook of each one.
Reports are made and plans for the
ensuing year discussed.
It is hoped that this year Hopkins may be able to have as many
delegates as before. All who desire to know more about the conference can see either Alec Barton,
'14, Bud Wagner, '12, or any of
the men who went to Westminister
last year. They will tell you that
it not only gives one the great time
that necessarily conies when a large
body of students get together, but
that it is a time when one's horizon in broadened and one is made
to see beyond his own college walls.
As the number of delegates will be
limited it is best to see about this
at once.

THE NEWS—LETTER, JANUARY 13, 1913.

FOOTBALL BLOWOUT IN GYM
About One Hundred Present, and Affair
Voted Huge Success— Mr. B. Howell
Griswold the Principal Speaker.

The usual football blowout and
Jollification meeting was held in the
gymnasium last Thursday evening.
Almost one hundred members of the
University were present. "Freddie"
Lee was chairman of the meeting
and called for speeches from the
various captains. Captain Huck of
the lacrosse team evidently believed
that "brevity is the soul of wit,"
..and so showed his wit by being
brief. Captain Pieper prophesied
a •successful baseball season and
urged undergraduates in particular
to come out for the team. As an
inducement he read the attractive
schedule Manager Getz has prepared. Captain Leibensperger of
the football team next delivered an
oration upon the "queer" season
that we have just completed and
offered hopes of brighter things
to come. Catlin spoke for the
track team, promising events with
Carlisle, Virginia, Pennsylvania,
Georgetown and Franklin and Marshall. Mr. B. Howell Griswold,
Jr., was the principal speaker. He
urged the athletes to practice "optimism" and not get discouraged because of defeat and try to make a
weaker schedule. "Nothing," he
he said, "is too good for Johns
Hopkins."
Then came the awarding of honors. Dr. Abercrombie awarded
medals to the members of the winning gymnasium team of the 1915
_Class. Hutzler receiv'ed a cup for
first place and Swartz a medal for

and track work were rewarded
then.
Several short speeches were made
by "Pete" Porter, Tappan, Hulburt
and Burgan. At intervals the assembled crowd was convulsed with
laughter by the antics of the "Ragamuffin Trio." Their program consisted of choice selections from the
operas, impromptus and fancy buck
dancing. They put everyone into
good spirits and made them ready
to enjoy to the full the bounteous
supply of "eats" the committe'e had
provided. No one went'away
hungry.
Cotillon on January 31.

The Board of Governors of the
Cotillon Club met last Tuesday and
announced that the next cotillon
would take place on Friday, January 31. At the meeting various
duties were assigned to each of the
governors, and attempts are being
made to make the next dance an extremely successful and pleasing affair. The names of those who will
receive have not yet been announced.
